question: Which condition at the center of the Earth keeps the inner core solid?

content.source_1: Pressure in Earth’s interior increases with depth because of the weight of overlying layers; estimates place pressures in the inner core at roughly 330–360 GPa (about 3–3.6 million atmospheres).
content.source_2: For iron (and most materials), the melting temperature increases with pressure; at multi‑GPa pressures, solid iron remains stable at much higher temperatures than at 1 atmosphere.
content.source_3: Seismic observations show that Earth’s inner core is solid while the outer core is liquid, based on how P- and S-waves travel through these layers.
content.source_4: Earth continuously loses heat to cold space through its surface; over geologic time the planet has cooled from a much hotter, partially molten early state.
content.source_5: A substance crystallizes when its temperature falls below its melting point; iron–nickel alloys solidify upon sufficient cooling.
content.source_6: Geophysical models indicate the solid inner core has been slowly growing as the core cools, with crystallization initiating at the center and progressing outward over time.
